newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan stocks close lower on political fears.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan stocks close lower on political fears.

text.p: Late profit-taking reversed early gains for Taiwan shares on Thursday on fears the domestic political situation will remain unstable in the near term, brokers said.
The weighted index lost 77.22 points, or 0.92 percent, to end at 8,349.85, well off an intra-day high of 8,479.32. Turnover was a heavy T$115.5 billion.

"People appear to be unsatisfied with the ruling party's decision of a partial cabinet reshuffle," said Alex Chan, an analyst of HSBC James Capel. "Local politics is expected to be unstable and uncertainty is the market's biggest enemy."

President Lee Teng-hui has asked Premier Lien Chan to "make some adjustments" in cabinet positions following growing public outcry over worsening social disorder. But Lee rejected Lien's resignation offer.
Brokers said the 8,500-point was a strong technical barrier.
Central bank governor Sheu Yuan-dong told the parliament on Thursday that the central bank had no plan to cut banks' reserve requirements at its scheduled board meeting at 0700 GMT.
"Sheu's comments fall into the market's expectations," Chan said.
Financial shares were weak, falling 1.33 percent.
Electronics were mixed, with leading chipmaker Taiwan Semiconductor falling T$1 or 0.97 percent to T$102.5.

Notebook computer maker Inventec Corp rose by the daily seven percent limit to T$353 on expected sound outlook after U.S. chipmaker Intel Corp on Wednesday launched its new Pentium II microprocessors.
A range of 8,250-8,450 was seen for Friday.
